inference:
Since $P$ lies in the interior of the pentagon, the only obtuse angle that it can form with $A$ and $B$ is $\angle APB$. The obtuse angles in $\triangle APB$ are those for which $m\angle APB>180^\circ$. Equivalently, these are the angles for which $m\angle APB>180^\circ-m\angle A-m\angle B$. So, the required probability is the integral of the joint density function of $P$ over the region in the interior of the pentagon where $m\angle APB>180^\circ-m\angle A-m\angle B$:
$$\begin{split} P(\angle APB \text{ is obtuse})&=\iint_{R} \frac{1}{\text{Area}(R)}dydx \\\ &=\frac{1}{\text{Area}(R)} \iint_{R} dy dx  \\\ &=\frac{1}{8} \int_{0}^4 \int_0^{4-y}  \ dx \ dy  \\\ &= \frac{1}{8} \int_0^4 (4-y) \ dy  \\\ &=\frac{1}{8} \left[ 4y-\frac{1}{2}y^2 \right]_0^4 \\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \end{split}$$

Final Answer: \boxed{$\frac{1}{2}$}. I hope it is correct.

The obtuse angles in $\triangle APB$ are those for which $m\angle APB>180^\circ$. Equivalently, these are the angles for which $m\angle APB>180^\circ-m\angle A-m\angle B$. So, the required probability is the integral of the joint density function of $P$ over the region in the interior of the pentagon where $m\angle APB>180^\circ-m\angle A-m\angle B$:
$$\begin{split} P(\angle APB \text{ is obtuse})&=\iint_{R} \frac{1}{\text{Area}(R)}dydx \\\ &=\frac{1}{\text{Area}(R)} \iint_{R} dy dx  \\\ &=\frac{1}{8} \int_{0}^4 \int_0^{4-y}  \ dx \ dy  \\\ &= \frac{1}{8} \int_0^4 (4-y) \ dy  \\\ &=\frac{1}{8} \left[ 4y-\frac{1}{2}y^2 \right]_0^4 \\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \end{split}$$
